On 2/28/11 2:07 AM, wiz_1984 wrote:
> Hi, I would like to use Heritrix to crawl websites of a country.
> Other than the apparent ccTLD (.sg,.us,.uk, etc) criteria, I want to
> determine the "nationality" of a website by its IP address.
>
> Therefore I will need to do a IP address lookup and decide to accept
> a link if it lies within a range of networks.
>
> I added the ExternalGeoLocationDecideRule in my DecideRuleSequence,
> but I have no idea about ExternalGeoLookupInterface. Looking at the
> source, it looks like I have to implement the class. After I
> implement the class (e.g. iplookup.class), what should I fill in for
> Implementation? Should it be iplookup or iplookup.class?
>
> Also, where should I keep this class file? Should I copy this class
> file to the DecideRule folder? Is rebuilding necessary?

Are you using a Heritrix 1.14.x release, or an H3 release?

You do need to provide your own class implementing 
ExternalGeoLookupInterface.

In H1, by looking at ExternalGeoLocationDecideRule, I can see that you 
specify the lookup class by full class name (eg: 
"com.example.geo.LookupInetAddress"), it must have a constructor taking 
a single String parameter (which is supplied the 'countryCode' value of 
ExternalGeoLocationDecideRule). If the class is anywhere on the 
'classpath' of the launched crawler, it should be found.

In H3, the lookup class is instantiated in the Spring-based 
configuration file like any other bean. That is, you can supply its 
class name and constructor/setter-based configuration in any of the ways 
allowed by that configuration format. The class will be found if 
anywhere on 'classpath' of the launched crawler. (Additionally, using 
the Spring configuration's option to create new implementation classes 
with scripting languages, it's even possible to implement the 
lookup-class inline in the configuration file.)

In neither case is a full rebuild required -- only that the new class be 
findable on the classpath when referenced. Still, if you're developing 
and debugging your new class to match the declared interface, you will 
probably want/need to have a development setup capable of building 
Heritrix, just to be able to iteratively write/test that new class.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA


> Thanks in advance.
